    Understanding the structure of objects

    V5-understanding-structure.Rmd
    library(ofpetrial)

    The ofpetrial package does not offer any package-specific object class. Rather, it uses the tibble (tbl_df, tbl, data.frame) object from the tibble package extensively because it is easy to handle list-columns with tibble. A list-columnd is just like a regular variable except it is a list. For example, take a look at the experiment plots made by make_exp_plots().

    seed_plot_info <-
  prep_plot_fs(
    input_name = "seed",
    machine_width = 60,
    section_num = 24,
    harvester_width = 30,
    plot_width = 30
  )

n_plot_info <-
  prep_plot_fs(
    input_name = "NH3",
    machine_width = 45,
    section_num = 1,
    harvester_width = 30,
    plot_width = 45
  )

exp_data <-
  make_exp_plots(
    input_plot_info = list(seed_plot_info, n_plot_info),
    boundary_data = system.file("extdata", "boundary-simple1.shp", package = "ofpetrial"),
    abline_data = system.file("extdata", "ab-line-simple1.shp", package = "ofpetrial"),
    abline_type = "free"
  )

    As you can see from below, there are four list-columns: headland, exp_plots, ab_lines, harvest_ab_lines.

    dplyr::glimpse(exp_data)
#> Rows: 2
#> Columns: 9
#> $ input_name       <chr> "seed", "NH3"
#> $ harvester_width  <dbl> 9.144, 9.144
#> $ plot_width       <dbl> 9.144, 13.716
#> $ field_sf         <MULTIPOLYGON [m]> MULTIPOLYGON (((352970.3 43..., MULTIPOLYGON (((35297â€¦
#> $ headland         <list> [<sf[1 x 1]>], [<sf[1 x 1]>]
#> $ exp_plots        <list> [<sf[365 x 4]>], [<sf[243 x 4]>]
#> $ ab_lines         <list> [<sf[1 x 2]>], [<sf[1 x 2]>]
#> $ harvest_ab_lines <list> [<sf[1 x 2]>], [<sf[1 x 2]>]
#> $ abline_type      <chr> "free", "free"

    Letâ€™s take a look at exp_plots. You can access them just like you access a regular variable using $ (or any other methods to pull them).

    class(exp_data$exp_plots)
#> [1] "list"

exp_data$exp_plots
#> [[1]]

    As you can see, it is a list of two sf objects of experiment plots. Since, it is a list, you can access the sf itself like this.

    exp_data$exp_plots[[1]]
#> Simple feature collection with 365 features and 3 fields
#> Geometry type: POLYGON
#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: 352988.4 ymin: 4331460 xmax: 353376.6 ymax: 4332198
#> Projected CRS: WGS 84 / UTM zone 28N
#> First 10 features:
#>    plot_id strip_id poly_line                       geometry
#> 1        1        1       1_1 POLYGON ((352997.6 4331460,...
#> 2        2        1       1_1 POLYGON ((352999.1 4331542,...
#> 3        3        1       1_1 POLYGON ((353000.5 4331624,...
#> 4        4        1       1_1 POLYGON ((353002 4331706, 3...
#> 5        5        1       1_1 POLYGON ((353003.5 4331788,...
#> 6        6        1       1_1 POLYGON ((353004.9 4331870,...
#> 7        1        2       1_1 POLYGON ((353006.7 4331460,...
#> 8        2        2       1_1 POLYGON ((353008.2 4331541,...
#> 9        3        2       1_1 POLYGON ((353009.6 4331621,...
#> 10       4        2       1_1 POLYGON ((353011.1 4331702,...

    Letâ€™s now assign rates to exp_plots of exp_data.

    #--- prepare rate information ---#
seed_rate_info <-
  prep_rates_s(
    plot_info = seed_plot_info,
    gc_rate = 32000,
    unit = "seed",
    min_rate = 16000,
    max_rate = 40000,
    num_rates = 5,
    design_type = "jcls"
  )
#> Trial rates were not directly specified, so the trial rates were calculated using min_rate, max_rate, gc_rate, and num_rates

n_rate_info <-
  prep_rates_s(
    plot_info = n_plot_info,
    gc_rate = 180,
    unit = "lb",
    rates = c(100, 140, 180, 220, 260),
    design_type = "ls",
    rank_seq_ws = c(5, 4, 3, 2, 1)
  )

#--- assign rates ---#
td <- assign_rates(exp_data, rate_info = list(seed_rate_info, n_rate_info))

    As you can see, td has a very similar structure and sets of variables (e.g., input_name and exp_plots were inherited from exp_data). This is not surprising because we just assigned rates to the experiment plots with assign_rates().

    dplyr::glimpse(td)
#> Rows: 2
#> Columns: 11
#> $ input_name       <chr> "seed", "NH3"
#> $ input_type       <list> "S", "N"
#> $ exp_plots        <list> [<sf[365 x 4]>], [<sf[243 x 4]>]
#> $ trial_design     <list> [<sf[366 x 5]>], [<sf[244 x 5]>]
#> $ design_type      <chr> "jcls", "ls"
#> $ unit             <chr> "seed", "lb"
#> $ abline_type      <chr> "free", "free"
#> $ ab_lines         <list> [<sf[1 x 2]>], [<sf[1 x 2]>]
#> $ harvest_ab_lines <list> [<sf[1 x 2]>], [<sf[1 x 2]>]
#> $ field_sf         <MULTIPOLYGON [m]> MULTIPOLYGON (((352970.3 43..., MULTIPOLYGON (((35297â€¦
#> $ harvester_width  <dbl> 9.144, 9.144

    A trial design (experiment plots with rates assigned) has a name of trial_design, which is also a list-column.

    #--- check the class ---#
class(td$trial_design)
#> [1] "list"

td$trial_design
#> [[1]]
#> Simple feature collection with 366 features and 4 fields

#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: -16.70078 ymin: 39.11957 xmax: -16.69604 ymax: 39.12696
#> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
#> First 10 features:
#>     rate strip_id plot_id       type                       geometry

    Since the individual trial designs are just sf, you can of course wrangle them direclty if you would like to.

    #--- get the trial design sf for the first input ---#
(
td_for_input_1 <- td$trial_design[[1]]
)
#> Simple feature collection with 366 features and 4 fields
#> Geometry type: POLYGON
#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: -16.70078 ymin: 39.11957 xmax: -16.69604 ymax: 39.12696
#> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
#> First 10 features:
#>     rate strip_id plot_id       type                       geometry
#> 1  26667        1       1 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1199...
#> 2  40000        1       2 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1206...
#> 3  32000        1       3 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1213...
#> 4  21333        1       4 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1221...
#> 5  16000        1       5 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1228...
#> 6  26667        1       6 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70048 39.1236...
#> 7  40000        2       1 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1199...
#> 8  32000        2       2 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1206...
#> 9  21333        2       3 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1213...
#> 10 16000        2       4 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1220...

#--- change the rates to all 0 ---#
(
td_for_input_1 <- dplyr::mutate(td_for_input_1, rate = 0)
)
#> Simple feature collection with 366 features and 4 fields
#> Geometry type: POLYGON
#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: -16.70078 ymin: 39.11957 xmax: -16.69604 ymax: 39.12696
#> Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84
#> First 10 features:
#>    rate strip_id plot_id       type                       geometry
#> 1     0        1       1 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1199...
#> 2     0        1       2 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1206...
#> 3     0        1       3 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1213...
#> 4     0        1       4 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1221...
#> 5     0        1       5 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70047 39.1228...
#> 6     0        1       6 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70048 39.1236...
#> 7     0        2       1 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1199...
#> 8     0        2       2 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1206...
#> 9     0        2       3 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1213...
#> 10    0        2       4 experiment POLYGON ((-16.70037 39.1220...

    Note that this does not alter tiral_design in td of course. So, if you want this to be reflected in td, you need to assign it back. A series of functions to change rates (change_rates_by_plot, change_rates_by_block, change_rates_by_strip) are designed to work directly work on td to avoid this tedious procedure. However, if you want to work directly on the trial design part, it is definitely possible.

    Many other functions return a tibble with list-columns. For example, check_alignment() checks whether the trial design would have a mixed treatment problem.

    check <- check_alignment(exp_data)

dplyr::glimpse(check)
#> Rows: 2
#> Columns: 6
#> $ input_name       <chr> "seed", "NH3"
#> $ harvest_ab_line  <LINESTRING [m]> LINESTRING (352992 4331403,..., LINESTRING (352992 43â€¦
#> $ overlap_data     <list> [<data.table[41 x 7]>], [<data.table[41 x 7]>]
#> $ harvester_path   <list> [<sf[45 x 3]>], [<sf[45 x 3]>]
#> $ g_path_alignment <list> [NULL, <environment: 0x1260e6678>, <enviroâ€¦
#> $ g_overlap        <list> [3.0000000, 4.0000000, 5.0000000, 6.0000000, 7.00000â€¦

    As you can see, its output has four list-columns and there are three different types of objects stored in them.

    • overlap_data: list of data.frames
    • harvester_path: list of sfs
    • g_path_alignment and g_overlap: list of ggplots

    Letâ€™s access the second of harvester_path.

    check$harvester_path[[2]]
#> Simple feature collection with 45 features and 2 fields
#> Geometry type: POLYGON
#> Dimension:     XY
#> Bounding box:  xmin: 352970.3 ymin: 4331423 xmax: 353395.2 ymax: 4332235
#> Projected CRS: WGS 84 / UTM zone 28N
#> First 10 features:
#>    ha_strip_id                       geometry  ha_area
#> 40           1 POLYGON ((352978.6 4331423,... 5790.435
#> 41           2 POLYGON ((352987.8 4331423,... 7300.628
#> 42           3 POLYGON ((352996.9 4331423,... 7300.696
#> 43           4 POLYGON ((353006.1 4331424,... 7300.765
#> 44           5 POLYGON ((353015.2 4331424,... 7300.834
#> 45           6 POLYGON ((353024.4 4331424,... 7300.902
#> 46           7 POLYGON ((353033.5 4331425,... 7300.971
#> 47           8 POLYGON ((353042.7 4331425,... 7301.040
#> 48           9 POLYGON ((353051.8 4331425,... 7301.108
#> 49          10 POLYGON ((353061 4331426, 3... 7301.177
